document.title: NYS Intermediate Level Science Core Curriculum

14D9C3F750E44DFDBB1F7F6FB109EF48.description: Since the Industrial Revolution, human activities have resulted in major pollution of air, water, and soil. Pollution has cumulative ecological effects such as acid rain, global warming, or ozone depletion. The survival of living things on our planet depends on the conservation and protection of Earth’s resources.

6B311A4A74E54F079AF950FA81691F91.description: Overpopulation by any species impacts the environment due to the increased use of resources. Human activities can bring about environmental degradation through resource acquisition, urban growth, land-use decisions, waste disposal, etc.

E3398C786BAD4F78B22D6B2330FE2D15.description: The environment may be altered through the activities of organisms. Alterations are sometimes abrupt. Some species may replace others over time, resulting in longterm gradual changes (ecological succession).

EF56EF89852848408A2B0E20F1EBB559.description:
In ecosystems, balance is the result of interactions between community members
and their environment.

DAED86D1BC724F58B73D05E77D4B3741.description: Describe the effects of environmental changes on humans and other populations

0EBDBE1ADF544F18A513D619CD914215.description: The environment may contain dangerous levels of substances (pollutants) that are harmful to organisms. Therefore, the good health of environments and individuals requires the monitoring of soil, air, and water, and taking steps to keep them safe.

0AE95EF8E1214A45853D200A150F8F1B.description: Some microorganisms are essential to the survival of other living things.

084C5004D173443A8C75152B2BA7DAC1.description: In all environments, organisms interact with one another in many ways. Relationships among organisms may be competitive, harmful, or beneficial. Some species have adapted to be dependent upon each other with the result that neither could survive without the other.

8332A27F801F451DABDCE154C16E5B7E.description: Given adequate resources and no disease or predators, populations (including humans) increase. Lack of resources, habitat destruction, and other factors such as predation and climate limit the growth of certain populations in the ecosystem.

F6E62F3BC9DD4AB4B8E0D1B8EC8EE85E.description:
A population consists of all individuals of a species that are found together at a
given place and time. Populations living in one place form a community. The community
and the physical factors with which it interacts compose an ecosystem.

C744994B19E14BC9B84011E739C9DD31.description:
Describe how living things, including humans, depend upon the living and nonliving environment
for their survival.

B6130AB95D4D4B40B213F6027EA7E265.description: Human decisions and activities have had a profound impact on the physical and living environment.

B26D4D5A83914ADDAF9CBA8A3500BA9B.description: Green plants are the producers of food which is used directly or indirectly by consumers.

7EC75D4D4E5B4C81BCE6A8190B7EDFDD.description: The major source of atmospheric oxygen is photosynthesis. Carbon dioxide is removed from the atmosphere and oxygen is released during photosynthesis.

F6B1EFDBD06240A8B5D95F7FBFFBD8B3.description:
Photosynthesis is carried on by green plants and other organisms containing
chlorophyll. In this process, the Sun’s energy is converted into and stored as chemical
energy in the form of a sugar. The quantity of sugar molecules increases in green plants
during photosynthesis in the presence of sunlight.

271819E30563424B8F7FD0D770ACA8D1.description:
Provide evidence that green plants make food and explain the significance of this process to
other organisms.

C865A73C493743A9BA3DDD5C395564AE.description: Matter is transferred from one organism to another and between organisms and their physical environment. Water, nitrogen, carbon dioxide, and oxygen are examples of substances cycled between the living and nonliving environment.

F305F47A3C2A4D4AA4882ACA88AD7B38.description: Food webs identify feeding relationships among producers, consumers, and decomposers in an ecosystem.

8F80B61302F6496188F3324578F52CF4.description:
Energy flows through ecosystems in one direction, usually from the Sun, through
producers to consumers and then to decomposers. This process may be visualized with
food chains or energy pyramids.

31832D5AB227490A92B857FCDDCCF177.description: Describe the flow of energy and matter through food chains and food webs.

6EACA3E985C642F3890C7A70B1819C4A.description: Plants and animals depend on each other and their physical environment.

4ED4ED0F8262403AA53810BB7781D953.description: Contraction of infectious disease, and personal behaviors such as use of toxic substances and some dietary habits, may interfere with one’s dynamic equilibrium. During pregnancy these conditions may also affect the development of the child. Some effects of these conditions are immediate; others may not appear for many years.

C8B25F182F6D42818A42B261410E353D.description: In order to maintain a balanced state, all organisms have a minimum daily intake of each type of nutrient based on species, size, age, sex, activity, etc. An imbalance in any of the nutrients might result in weight gain, weight loss, or a diseased state.

BA832E5E0E9848A0BC7A5B5F6EBEA5B9.description: Energy in foods is measured in Calories. The total caloric value of each type of food varies. The number of Calories a person requires varies from person to person.

41105E1E11DC4CD3A8608672BD6F68F4.description: Metabolism is the sum of all chemical reactions in an organism. Metabolism can be influenced by hormones, exercise, diet, and aging.

7F49B085189B451A9A1799F49DBC64CA.description:
Foods contain a variety of substances, which include carbohydrates, fats, vitamins,
proteins, minerals, and water. Each substance is vital to the survival of the organism.

4E79F9CD84834D56BE96F21089A1A187.description:
Food provides molecules that serve as fuel and building material for all organisms.
All living things, including plants, must release energy from their food, using it to carry
on their life processes.

6E4584BD133546848795B7D913ED5601.description:
Describe the importance of major nutrients, vitamins, and minerals in maintaining health and
promoting growth, and explain the need for a constant input of energy for living organisms.

5B80C006E9584EC7B794C1945A8CECB4.description:
The survival of an organism depends on its ability to sense and respond to its
external environment.

D70DE92F1DF84C648C3C88C79EBBF038.description:
Regulation of an organism’s internal environment involves sensing the internal
environment and changing physiological activities to keep conditions within the range
required for survival. Regulation includes a variety of nervous and hormonal feedback
systems.

85DFCD2DD4044A3D9BC0AC2BC27E21F7.description:
Herbivores obtain energy from plants. Carnivores obtain energy from animals.
Omnivores obtain energy from both plants and animals. Decomposers, such as bacteria
and fungi, obtain energy by consuming wastes and/or dead organisms.

3B2272B57D0248F58D7D4EB61FA4ABFC.description:
The methods for obtaining nutrients vary among organisms. Producers, such as
green plants, use light energy to make their food. Consumers, such as animals, take in
energy-rich foods.

E019AE2C185F4F73A9E736B51B92FD11.description:
All organisms require energy to survive. The amount of energy needed and the
method for obtaining this energy vary among cells. Some cells use oxygen to release the
energy stored in food.

05B35156B13E44C28DF4640BAA9FB34A.description:
An organism’s overall body plan and its environment determine the way that the
organism carries out the life processes.

020D942BFDA046698ECC916223D6107F.description:
Animals and plants have a great variety of body plans and internal structures that
contribute to their ability to maintain a balanced condition

A0F597DCDA8E459FA1FE559CC99B4CCE.description:
Compare the way a variety of living specimens carry out basic life functions and maintain
dynamic equilibrium.

F4A0B3B46D4049FD87DAB0435800E5F1.description: Organisms maintain a dynamic equilibrium that sustains life.

91A78DBA18D5405A8873F063B24BC536.description: Cancers are a result of abnormal cell division.

9B364660BA2A42A4B861F3B440534A59.description:
Another type of cell division accounts for the production of egg and sperm cells in
sexually reproducing organisms. The eggs and sperm resulting from this type of cell
division contain one-half of the hereditary information.

3F635FDCB3C2456B935570E8D6EDEC22.description:
In one type of cell division, chromosomes are duplicated and then separated into
two identical and complete sets to be passed to each of the two resulting cells. In this
type of cell division, the hereditary information is identical in all the cells that result.

1F72778A932A4EEFB2D0D437F73AE0C1.description:
In multicellular organisms, cell division is responsible for growth, maintenance,
and repair. In some one-celled organisms, cell division is a method of asexual
reproduction.

15C43A9748B24B5294D5DA2ED98D270F.description: Observe and describe cell division at the microscopic level and its macroscopic effects

43E69A5551AE47E6B6D48E0F0055502E.description: As an individual organism ages, various body structures and functions change.

BD9F5778582C46D5A32AF22F04F75D96.description:
Patterns of development vary among plants. In seed-bearing plants, seeds contain
stored food for early development. Their later development into adulthood is characterized
by varying patterns of growth from species to species.

2E39E2F5D59A4EEAB5C342300E00937C.description:
Patterns of development vary among animals. In some species the young resemble
the adult, while in others they do not. Some insects and amphibians undergo metamorphosis
as they mature.

B7A2753B3074485397F85E33F07023C5.description:
Various body structures and functions change as an organism goes through its life
cycle.

E93EB9D7353A4F2DBF80C68402FF0E85.description:
In humans, the fertilized egg grows into tissue which develops into organs and
organ systems before birth.

E0795CC0D61A4D5C9BC2027D4A246558.description:
Multicellular organisms exhibit complex changes in development, which begin
after fertilization. The fertilized egg undergoes numerous cellular divisions that will
result in a multicellular organism, with each cell having identical genetic information

EFFC849E96344387B411098020089DB4.description:
Observe and describe developmental patterns in selected plants and animals (e.g., insects, frogs,
humans, seed-bearing plants).

F1098067051F49C2BDFF390A59AF633D.description:
In sexual reproduction, sperm and egg each carry one-half of the genetic information
for the new individual. Therefore, the fertilized egg contains genetic information
from each parent.

8EC84EC391974D9F823E76C9AE9265D4.description:
The male sex cell is the sperm. The female sex cell is the egg. The fertilization of an
egg by a sperm results in a fertilized egg.

6490121C8EEC4CFBAD9D98C410B62EC5.description: Explain the role of sperm and egg cells in sexual reproduction.

EC67020466FE4B93A928EA0ED1BFA1FD.description: Fertilization and/or development in organisms may be internal or external.

706F89092E3E4B21AB1C82EA4A5537B4.description:
Methods of sexual reproduction depend upon the species. All methods involve the
merging of sex cells to begin the development of a new individual. In many species,
including plants and humans, eggs and sperm are produced.

2D9E54D4A0AB4770AA02589CE4A27858.description:
There are many methods of asexual reproduction, including division of a cell into
two cells, or separation of part of an animal or plant from the parent, resulting in the
growth of another individual.

8275BA40B2FA4E24AE62C7B3F34FD342.description:
Some organisms reproduce asexually. Other organisms reproduce sexually. Some
organisms can reproduce both sexually and asexually.

EC132ED2BBBB43EE9140CCB9B983100E.description:
Observe and describe the variations in reproductive patterns of organisms, including asexual
and sexual reproduction.

ECDBB77302ED4363899DC0F69F0371F2.description: The continuity of life is sustained through reproduction and development.

52EAC25931824BBD9A906E1CBE27A15F.description:
Although the time needed for change in a species is usually great, some species of
insects and bacteria have undergone significant change in just a few years.

1505E695F2C94E9D84B60C546B20C1D6.description:
Many thousands of layers of sedimentary rock provide evidence for the long history
of Earth and for the long history of changing lifeforms whose remains are found in
the rocks. Recently deposited rock layers are more likely to contain fossils resembling
existing species.

B76A92E08F744061B75A24B47A3ECCF1.description:
Extinction of a species occurs when the environment changes and the adaptive
characteristics of a species are insufficient to permit its survival. Extinction of species is
common. Fossils are evidence that a great variety of species existed in the past.

62C6E47674094B91870C7C796A70E5AC.description:
In all environments, organisms with similar needs may compete with one another
for resources

B5C01455B97C4A30892C76A41DE72DF5.description:
Describe factors responsible for competition within species and the significance of that
competition.

789919BD2EC4458787946E9EFD49C729.description: Human activities such as selective breeding and advances in genetic engineering may affect the variations of species.

E06A7BE6B0C34129A370BE6C23A4AE2C.description: Changes in environmental conditions can affect the survival of individual organisms with a particular trait. Small differences between parents and offspring can accumulate in successive generations so that descendants are very different from their ancestors. Individual organisms with certain traits are more likely to survive and have offspring than individuals without those traits.

5EBA0AA7B41B40628035F8469FE137E8.description:
The processes of sexual reproduction and mutation have given rise to a variety of
traits within a species.

16A62290DF054DFCB77364160D866D30.description:
Describe sources of variation in organisms and their structures and relate the variations to
survival.

2A5CAA69C15F48C6958E97B9574E2A08.description: Individual organisms and species change over time.

19CB5F08EF0B450C9FA677FF33C81416.description: The probability of traits being expressed can be determined using models of genetic inheritance. Some models of prediction are pedigree charts and Punnett squares.

89CD294F3AE54047BD7B85196F56AFC6.description: Some genes are dominant and some are recessive. Some traits are inherited by mechanisms other than dominance and recessiveness.

59C81427610D4C8E8B2D14B981C58BDE.description: In all organisms, genetic traits are passed on from generation to generation.

E3642186F6E3415EB2085E69039B2CFA.description: Describe simple mechanisms related to the inheritance of some physical traits in offspring.

8E46C7E0A4234A1BB9486BB93947BA5D.description: In sexual reproduction typically half of the genes come from each parent. Sexually produced offspring are not identical to either parent.

7C16A168ECE34F35ACB3318EE31B0A62.description: In asexual reproduction, all the genes come from a single parent. Asexually produced offspring are genetically identical to the parent.

303D986D2A1F4874B8235E8D30995E8E.description: Each human cell contains a copy of all the genes needed to produce a human being.

688686F0A70247B68B80D10016A422BF.description: Each gene carries a single unit of information. A single inherited trait of an individual can be determined by one pair or by many pairs of genes. A human cell contains thousands of different genes.

ED480A10C85A49C4AF91AE4E5884CE0F.description:
Hereditary information is contained in genes. Genes are composed of DNA that
makes up the chromosomes of cells.

6AC017AA1BD14098B541B372ADF71430.description:
Describe sexual and asexual mechanisms for passing genetic materials from generation to
generation.

3FFC101C86A8402F8895EB7000EA2C97.description:
Organisms inherit genetic information in a variety of ways that result in continuity of structure and function
between parents and offspring.

A03C84939AAC49E2A2497B6A8E6A7D80.description:
Disease breaks down the structures or functions of an organism. Some diseases are
the result of failures of the system. Other diseases are the result of damage by infection
from other organisms (germ theory). Specialized cells protect the body from infectious
disease. The chemicals they produce identify and destroy microbes that enter the body.

02C1077D023A4AA0A5058A3ACFBF6F53.description:
The male and female reproductive systems are responsible for producing sex cells
necessary for the production of offspring.

67F576BB1D464F2D9FB20C48E2DA6135.description:
The nervous and endocrine systems interact to control and coordinate the body’s
responses to changes in the environment, and to regulate growth, development, and
reproduction. Hormones are chemicals produced by the endocrine system; hormones
regulate many body functions.

7DA7CEEE6A024F8BBB6B37DF8131A9DE.description:
Locomotion, necessary to escape danger, obtain food and shelter, and reproduce, is
accomplished by the interaction of the skeletal and muscular systems, and coordinated
by the nervous system.

920F65751FA140798A1CE74C760949C3.description:
The circulatory system moves substances to and from cells, where they are needed
or produced, responding to changing demands.

80AF763B1A8D476F8B737C204A6DEB45.description:
The excretory system functions in the disposal of dissolved waste molecules, the
elimination of liquid and gaseous wastes, and the removal of excess heat energy.

CEB4D99E17DD425E95ABC9095D731359.description:
During respiration, cells use oxygen to release the energy stored in food. The respiratory
system supplies oxygen and removes carbon dioxide (gas exchange).

FDDF8551D3BC4925BFDBD2FE6CAD79A0.description:
The digestive system consists of organs that are responsible for the mechanical and
chemical breakdown of food. The breakdown process results in molecules that can be
absorbed and transported to cells.

5A2B7D02EDDE40538DB3228DC29DB079.description:
Tissues, organs, and organ systems help to provide all cells with nutrients, oxygen,
and waste removal.

EDB35AD4756843DABA3DDB7887CA0900.description:
Each system is composed of organs and tissues which perform specific functions
and interact with each other, e.g., digestion, gas exchange, excretion, circulation, locomotion,
control, coordination, reproduction, and protection from disease.

C72F62C2DE0E4608948BD55290A73F9E.description: Explain the functioning of the major human organ systems and their interactions

65E7F257B82642C3BB2713D70D2873F9.description: Living things are classified by shared characteristics on the cellular and organism level. In classifying organisms, biologists consider details of internal and external structures. Biological classification systems are arranged from general (kingdom) to specific (species).

449C7906F5BD4FF881D356B40D910498.description: Multicellular animals often have similar organs and specialized systems for carrying out major life activities.

494C69112B914C1B806ADFB32CBFEB3D.description: Many plants have roots, stems, leaves, and reproductive structures. These organized groups of tissues are responsible for a plant’s life activities.

3ED884CA50C24C588FC968BDAFE47DC9.description:
Cells are organized for more effective functioning in multicellular organisms.
Levels of organization for structure and function of a multicellular organism include
cells, tissues, organs, and organ systems.

A31E00C63A1C457D8C1BD0276826D6C1.description: Some organisms are single cells; others, including humans, are multicellular.

9643C99812194CAABFC91A29B99461E6.description:
Most cells have cell membranes, genetic material, and cytoplasm. Some cells have
a cell wall and/or chloroplasts. Many cells have a nucleus.

1557A46CBF8343E389BD8D4C289D5DC8.description:
The way in which cells function is similar in all living things. Cells grow and
divide, producing more cells. Cells take in nutrients, which they use to provide energy
for the work that cells do and to make the materials that a cell or an organism needs

C79AE54D105B4D5C89EF4048E3DD65F9.description:
Living things are composed of cells. Cells provide structure and carry on major
functions to sustain life. Cells are usually microscopic in size.

5EC98FD1C0BB4D14AD076B5EF1C3412C.description: Compare and contrast the parts of plants, animals, and one-celled organisms

B98AD06EF5A047E484E4E1138BF9CF48.description: Living things are both similar to and different from each other and from nonliving things.

F98AC904E980464DAAF338BAD703697D.description: Students will understand and apply scientific concepts, principles, and theories pertaining to the physical setting and living environment and recognize the historical development of ideas in science.
